title: Getting started with ggpatina
text: ggpatina small toolkit giving ggplot2* figures analog makeover. Effects applied plot rendered: build normal plot, convert magick image as_magick(), pass image one patina filters. package also includes lightweight themes helpers period fonts whole graphic carries vibe. Code chunks evaluated vignette built, plots produce show automatically. vignette walks several effects illustrate typical workflow. * plots can applied figure provided converted magick object, convenience functions workflows assume ggplot input.

title: Getting started with ggpatina
text: ’ll start basic scatter plot gradually turn blueprint.
code: # build the plot as usual base <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg)) +   geom_point(aes(shape = factor(cyl))) +   geom_smooth(se = FALSE, linewidth = 0.5) +   labs(title = "Fuel efficiency by weight",        x = "Weight (1000 lb)", y = "MPG", color = "Cyl") +   theme_minimal()  # convert to a magick image and apply the blueprint patina base |>   # Add some hand-drawn effect (and convert to image)   hand_drawn_wiggle(width=3, height=2) |>   # Apply a blueprint patina   patina_blueprint() #> Ignoring unknown labels: #> • colour : "Cyl" #> `geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Getting started with ggpatina
text: transparency slide effect mimics projected slide.
code: # start from the base scatter plot base <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg)) +    geom_point(color = "steelblue") +   ggtitle("Fuel efficiency")  # add the slide-style theme and nice font p_slide <- base + theme_transparency() + period_font_theme("slide-1980s")  # render to a magick image, then give it slide artifacts img <- as_magick(p_slide, width=3, height=2) slideify_transparency(img)

title: Getting started with ggpatina
text: Give impression plot copied dusty journal library.
code: # start from the base scatter plot base <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg)) +    geom_point(size=0.5) +   labs(     caption = "Figure 1. Imapact of vehicle size on fuel efficiency."   )  # add an old school theme and font p_journal <- base + theme_journal_1930s() + period_font_theme()  # render to a magick image, then give it slide artifacts img <- as_magick(p_journal, width=2, height=1.5) scanify_journal(img)

title: Getting started with ggpatina
text: Ink bleed gives photocopied cheaply printed feel edges blur ink spreads paper.
code: # reuse the base scatter plot base <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg)) +    geom_point() +   labs(     title = "Nation's fuel economy problem driven by size",     caption = "Expert's analysis of cars released last year",     y = "MPG",     x = "Weight (x1000 lb)"   )  # newspaper theme sets up the flat tones p_news <- base + theme_newspaper()  # convert and apply effects as_magick(p_news, width=3, height=2) |>   patina_newspaper()

title: Getting started with ggpatina
text: Warm colors soft fade evoke look vintage Kodachrome film.
code: base <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg)) + geom_point(color = "firebrick") p_koda <- base + theme_transparency() img <- as_magick(p_koda, width=3, height=2) patina_kodachrome(img)

title: Getting started with ggpatina
text: effect mimics low-resolution television capture.
code: base <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg)) + geom_point(color = "goldenrod") p_cast <- base + theme_newscast() img <- as_magick(p_cast, width=3, height=2) patina_newscast(img)

title: Getting started with ggpatina
text: Misaligned colors grain suggest worn-photocopier.  examples just starting point. Combine effects themes give plots era’s personality.
code: base <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg)) + geom_point() img <- as_magick(base, width=3, height=2) patina_photocopy(img)

title: Vibe Coding
text: package developed using vibe coding. many approaches building package using AI, started basic “possible?” question ChatGPT’s new (--time) version 5 model, grew organically . page designed walk series prompts tasks used create package. interested narrative journey just want walk chat , see link. appreciate great deal controversy use AI arts software development. little project seem worth investment real time develop, need meet sort rigorous standard application. Even case, GPT needed great deal hand-holding direction meet minimum seeking. wouldn’t consider project endorsement AI (melodramatically) claim vibe coding just good classic coding, tinkerer can’t resist trying new (improved) tool.

title: Vibe Coding
text: always fan screenshots scanned figures old journals looked. plots look someone uses image took slide containing plot elsewhere (speaking controversies). Accompanying section examples pdfs sitting around. Nice, official scan released publisher. : Collander R. Partition Organic Compounds Higher Alcohols Water. Acta Chemica Scandinavica. 1951;5:774-780. Sloppy, phone-based scan. : Higuchi WI, Higuchi T. Theoretical Analysis Diffusional Movement Heterogeneous Barriers. J Pharm Ass (Scientific ed.). 1960 Sep 1;49(9):598-606. (Scanned , circa 2014) Edward Tufte’s books rich examples ’m referencing (least terms scanned plots variety popular academic sources). read works find plots various age, style quality; museum data visualization inspire inform. point plots appearance seem like meant something someone point motivated capture collect . small visual effect imbue plot authentic candid backstory, can fun give trivial plot appearance importance. admiration style plot mind OpenAI rolled current-newest ChatGPT model 5, claimed substantial advancements generative code quality improvement Thinking feature introduced previous generation. fully skeptical code produced tools, also enjoy using ChatGPR brainstorming wanted give model go.

title: Vibe Coding
text: started question obvious answer: possible develop R package takes ggplot grobs makes look photographed old transparency slide? like scanned old journal (hand drawn)? ChatGPT told course , laid rough framework form basis package: provided filters interesting names slideify_transparency() scanify_journal(), kept forever. address desire capture hand-drawn appearance older plots/diagrams, chatbot took interesting approach rendering plot svg, wobbling vectors rasterizing result magick image. refreshed build R package, nice treat. functions needed tested refined, features mode chugging . wanted know best way (chatbot’s perspective) one add period specific fonts plot, users easily get plot looked like came 1920s journal article. solution provided function assigned certain eras publication types known Google fonts, systemfont showtext render image. big headache also set aside later. point, think cool maybe wanted work . ChatGPT, prompter coder. good package needs name sell , think “good” package still wanted good name. ChatGPT provided options, picked first one also thought best: ggpatina. issue suggestions many emphatic “ggplot2 extension” (“gg” prefix); don’t think merely taking grob work magick image makes package ggplot2 extension. Nevertheless, kept “gg” prefix, tried make improvements earn . Now, fully ready actually run project, asked ChatGPT give everything far package. awkwardly provided files copy paste kindly said: > Please provide package zip file ggpatina.zip

title: Vibe Coding
text: much love Motor Trends analysis 32 cars released 1972-1974, ’ll go ahead use penguins section. Just switch . started testing functions unsystematically, patina_ink_bleed(). first version ChatGPT provided didn’t much:  great. bleed effect getting hidden. sent ChatGPT message: “code doesn’t seem effect” along function. rewrote compositing logic—building proper mask dark ink, expanding feathering , using alpha channel colored bleed layer multiplies plot. Much better. became debugging pattern: test function, report ’s working, get refined version.
code: peng_p <- ggplot(penguins, aes(x = flipper_len)) +     geom_point(aes(y = bill_len)) +     geom_text(aes(x = 220, y = 28, label = "Bill Length, mm"), size=2) +     geom_hline(yintercept = 25) +     geom_point(aes(y = bill_dep)) +     geom_text(aes(x = 220, y = 22, label = "Bill Depth, mm"), size=2) +     labs(         x = "Flipper Length, mm",         y = ""     ) peng_p |> as_magick(width = 2.5, height=2) |> patina_ink_bleed()

title: Vibe Coding
text: period fonts system turned adventure. First attempt journal-1960s era gave error: “Crimson Pro available, using sans instead.” install_if_missing set TRUE, something clearly wrong. issue: systemfonts::match_font() can’t see fonts registered via sysfonts/showtext—checks system-installed fonts. ChatGPT kept trying validate fonts existed registering , created circular problem. pushed just register fonts Google Fonts trust ’d available. required using safe aliases (crimson_pro instead "Crimson Pro") skipping validation step entirely. fixed font registration, revealed bigger problem: function enabling showtext_auto() globally, affected every subsequent plot R session. acceptable. several iterations ChatGPT suggested toggling showtext , asked: “Can use withr use setting without changing globally plot rendered?” breakthrough. final solution uses withr::defer() create scoped wrappers: Now print_st() ggsave_st() enable showtext just single operation. global state changes.
code: with_showtext_auto <- function(expr) {   withr::defer({     showtext::showtext_auto(FALSE)     showtext::showtext_opts()   }, parent.frame())   showtext::showtext_auto(TRUE)   showtext::showtext_opts(dpi = 300)   force(expr) }

title: Vibe Coding
text: hand-drawn wiggle effect went iterations. ChatGPT’s initial approach: render plot SVG, apply feTurbulence displacement filter, rasterize. Conceptually elegant. practice, debugging nightmare. First issue reported: “theme info fonts text lost leave affect_text=TRUE .” SVG filter wrapping <style> block inside filtered group, librsvg ignores. got fixed, discovered fonts registered via showtext weren’t available SVG renderer anyway—sees system-installed fonts. next solution split rendering: warp shapes via SVG displacement, render text separately ragg (respects showtext fonts), composite layers. mostly worked, except noticed “weirdly large margin added text elements.” went multiple debugging rounds trying fix filter regions, viewBox settings, edge masking. Nothing worked consistently. finally said: “Perhaps need rethink whole approach… Can try instead rewrite whole functionality just post-processing filter?” rewrite simplified everything: pure raster displacement. Render full plot ragg, generate 2-channel displacement map Gaussian noise, apply using magick’s displace operator. Much simpler. Actually worked. still wanted ability wobble just plot panel keeping titles crisp—key feature figures want hand-drawn data professional annotation. required measuring actual panel viewport bounds ggplot layout. solution turned quite clever: Debugging bounding box calculation tedious. one point report: “Now see bounding box ’s way . thought calculating edge, realized ’s .” coordinate system math completely wrong. corrected debugging output provided, worked beautifully—precise panel targeting smooth edge feathering.
code: panel_mask_from_plot <- function(p, width, height, dpi, feather = 10,                                  expand_px = c(0L, 0L), include_axes = TRUE, ...) {   # 1. Render plot to ragg device at exact target size   # 2. Call grid.force() to materialize all viewports   # 3. Use grid.ls() to find viewports with "panel" or "axis" in names   # 4. Convert NPC coordinates to device pixels via grid::deviceLoc()   # 5. Union all panel/axis boxes into single bounding box   # 6. Add feathering and return magick mask }

title: Vibe Coding
text: infrastructure solid, asked presets: “old newspaper; old newscast; old educational film.” came together faster since magick operation patterns established. needed visual refinement. newspaper halftone “really hard see” default settings—asked adjustable parameters control effect strength. photocopy “washed ”—added ghost_opacity protect_lines parameters control much effect washes versus re-inks strokes. journal scan “weird gray band top”—scanner shadow compositing title instead looking like behind content. fix involved extending canvas upward, drawing shadow top margin, rotating entire page shadow rotates . One typical bug caught: ChatGPT confidently wrote magick::image_sepia_tone(). reported: “magick sepia function doesn’t exist.” immediately rewrote using image_colorize() manual sepia calculations. hallucinations happened regularly—use functions don’t exist, course-correct caught.

title: Vibe Coding
text: ChatGPT fundamentally can’t make visual design decisions. transparency slide light leak “taking away plot image much,” tell specifically favor original image blend. Kodachrome warmth subtle, specified stronger colorization values. CRT scanlines invisible small sizes, adjusted scan_strength parameter visible overwhelming. Every effect went visual tuning loop. ChatGPT generate something technically correct aesthetically wrong. ’d test , describe seeing (“washed ”, “barely noticeable”, “weird margin”), request specific changes. adjust underlying magick operations accordingly. worked articulate visual problem translate parameter adjustments.

title: Vibe Coding
text: journal themes (1900s, 1930s, 1960s) came together quickly ChatGPT learned use %+replace% (causes cryptic ggplot2 errors) avoid touching user-specified text sizes. README, ChatGPT initially wanted extensive documentation. kept pushing back: “like simple readme.Rmd… simpler version provided earlier.” iterated hit right tone—concise, example-focused, grab--go code snippets rather lengthy explanations.

title: Vibe Coding
text: Total time investment: maybe 3-4 hours spread across several sessions prompting, testing, iteration. ChatGPT wrote approximately 95% code line count. provided 100% direction, quality control, aesthetic judgment. ChatGPT good : Generating boilerplate (roxygen documentation, package structure, utility functions) Implementing well-defined image operations described desired visual effect Refactoring code pointed architectural problems Debugging specific errors provided clear error messages terrible : Anticipating edge cases subtle rendering bugs Knowing magick/ggplot2 functions actually exist versus hallucinating Understanding R’s graphics system (grid, viewports, coordinate systems) without detailed guidance Making visual aesthetic design decisions Avoiding unnecessary complexity key making collaboration work: rapid iteration immediate testing. tested function soon written, identified exactly broke looked wrong, described problem precisely. ChatGPT apply fix. didn’t work, ’d give one round, suggest completely different approach needed. use workflow production software needs reliable maintainable? Maybe. experimental package exploring niche aesthetic idea wouldn’t bothered coding manually? Definitely. boundaries clear: provided vision, taste, verification. ChatGPT provided implementation speed tireless iteration. struggled viewport measurement debugging, working step--step felt oddly like teaching. Even AI apparently needs learn R’s graphics system wonderfully arcane. result isn’t life-changing software, ’s functional, documented package scratches specific aesthetic itch ’ve years old journal figures vintage media. hours prompting testing, ’s enough.

code: @Manual{,   title = {ggpatina: Period Aesthetics and Analog Aging Effects for Figures},   author = {John Prybylski},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://jprybylski.github.io/ggpatina/}, }

what: Period Aesthetics and Analog Aging Effects for Figures
title: Period Aesthetics and Analog Aging Effects for Figures
text: Make ggplot2 figures look like scanned, photocopied, projected old slides, captured CRT—without losing plot. package adds lightweight, composable patina filters (magick images), tiny set journal-era themes, panel-aware hand-drawn wobble “annotated human” vibe. Built vibe-coding project ChatGPT (GPT-5 Thinking).

title: Period Aesthetics and Analog Aging Effects for Figures
code: # Install released version from CRAN install.packages("ggpatina")  # Install development version from GitHub pak::pak("jprybylski/ggpatina")

what: What this package tries to do
title: Period Aesthetics and Analog Aging Effects for Figures
text: Old-school vibes, minimal hassle. One-liners get “old newspaper”, “1970s transparency slide”, “1980s newscast/CRT”, “educational film” looks. Post-processing, plotting. keep ggplot; patinas work magick-image rendered plot. Fonts without global side-effects. Swap period-appropriate families (e.g., IM FELL, Crimson Pro) place via apply_period_fonts() (uses showtext safely). Panel-aware wobble. Hand-drawn raster wobble can target just data panel (axes included) titles margins stay crisp. Print-friendly themes. restrained “journal” themes don’t fight sizes.

title: Period Aesthetics and Analog Aging Effects for Figures
code: library(ggplot2) library(magick) #> Linking to ImageMagick 6.9.12.98 #> Enabled features: cairo, freetype, fftw, ghostscript, heic, lcms, pango, raw, rsvg, webp #> Disabled features: fontconfig, x11 library(ggpatina)  # A vanilla plot p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg, color = factor(cyl))) +   geom_point() +   geom_smooth(se = FALSE, linewidth = 0.5, color = "black") +   labs(title = "Fuel economy by weight",        x = "Weight (1000 lb)", y = "MPG", color = "Cyl")  # 1) Period fonts (fonts only; no size changes) p_fonts <- apply_period_fonts(p, era = "journal-1960s", scope = "targeted")  # 2) Hand-drawn wobble (panel-aware; leave text crisp) img_wobble <- hand_drawn_wiggle(   p_fonts, width = 2, height = 1.5, dpi = 300,  affect_text = FALSE, fill_bg = "white" ) #> `geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'  # 3) Patina: old journal scan (sepia/mono + dither + slight tilt) # Tip: provide a paper texture path for extra authenticity, e.g. "inst/extdata/paper_news.jpg" img_scan <- scanify_journal(   img_wobble,   paper   = NULL,   # or "path/to/paper_texture.jpg"   sepia   = TRUE,   dither  = TRUE,   tilt_deg = 0.6,   pad_top_px = 3 )  image_write(img_scan, path = "man/figures/scanify_journal.png", format = "png")

title: Period Aesthetics and Analog Aging Effects for Figures
code: # ---------- 1) Transparency slide (Kodachrome-ish transparency) ---------- # Slight keystone + gentle vignette; keep the leak modest so plot stays readable img_slide <- slideify_transparency(   img_wobble,   ca_px = 4L,   leak_strength = 0.14,   # was 0.18; a touch lighter for small images   vignette      = 0.22,   skew          = 0.010,  # keystone ~1% of width   grain         = 0.55    # give slide film a bit of tooth ) image_write(img_slide, path = "man/figures/slide.png", format = "png") # ---------- 2) Old newscast / CRT ---------- # Pick scanline period from image height so it stays visible but not overbearing img_crt <- patina_newscast(   img_wobble,   scan_strength = 0.28,  # slightly stronger lines for clarity at small dims   ca_px         = 1L,    # tiny red/blue offset   glow          = 0.22,   vignette      = 0.18,   noise         = 0.28 ) image_write(img_crt, path = "man/figures/crt.png", format = "png") # ---------- 3) Photocopy ---------- img_copy <- patina_photocopy(   img_wobble,   ghost_opacity = 0.10,   # adjustable "washout" (lower = less washed out)   banding       = 0.10,   tilt_deg      = 0.35,   protect_lines = 0.85 ) image_write(img_copy, path = "man/figures/photocopy.png", format = "png") # ---------- 4) Educational film (animated GIF) ---------- # A short loop with mild gate weave; pass film params via ... to your patina img_film <- animate_edu_film(   img_wobble,   n_frames = 20,   fps      = 10,   max_dust = 0.3,   # forwarded to patina_edu_film():   warmth   = 0.28,   grain    = 0.55,   vignette = 0.20,   dust_polarity = "mixed", # allows some darker dust   scratches= 5L,   jitter   = 0.1  # a little extra weave for motion to read ) image_write(img_film, path = "man/figures/film.gif", format = "gif")

title: Period Aesthetics and Analog Aging Effects for Figures
code: p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg, color = factor(cyl))) + geom_point() p + theme_newspaper() p + theme_edu_film() p + theme_newscast()

title: Period Aesthetics and Analog Aging Effects for Figures
code: p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg, color = factor(cyl))) + geom_point() p + theme_journal_1900s() p + theme_journal_1930s() p + theme_journal_1960s()

title: Period Aesthetics and Analog Aging Effects for Figures
text: Issues PRs welcome—especially new patina presets small, readable defaults.

title: Animate an educational-film segment — animate_edu_film
text: Builds animated GIF short 16mm instructional clip gate weave, flicker, per-frame dust.

title: Animate an educational-film segment — animate_edu_film
code: animate_edu_film(   img,   n_frames = 48,   fps = 10,   weave_deg = 0.1,   jitter_xy = 0.1,   flicker = 0.06,   loop = 0,   bg = "black",   seed = NULL,   write_gif = NULL,   max_dust = 0.3,   ... )

title: Animate an educational-film segment — animate_edu_film
text: img magick image (rasterized ggplot) n_frames number frames (e.g., 48) fps frames per second (e.g., 10) weave_deg max rotation (deg) gate weave (per-frame) jitter_xy max XY translation pixels (per-frame) flicker amplitude brightness flicker (0..0.2 ~ gentle) loop 0 = loop forever (GIF), otherwise number loops bg background color used translating/rotating (usually "black") seed optional integer; set, dust/scratches vary per-frame deterministically write_gif optional file path; provided, writes GIF also returns max_dust using fixed dust ..., generate random dust form 0...max_dust ... passed patina_edu_film() (e.g., warmth, grain, dust_polarity, dust_n, scratches)

title: Animate an educational-film segment — animate_edu_film
text: animated magick-image (GIF). write_gif provided, file also written.

title: Animate an educational-film segment — animate_edu_film
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ if (requireNamespace("magick", quietly = TRUE)) {   img <- magick::image_blank(100, 100, "white")   animate_edu_film(img, n_frames = 5, fps = 2) } } # }

what: Apply period fonts in place — apply_period_fonts
title: Apply period fonts in place — apply_period_fonts
text: Changes family text elements ggplot, preserving size, face, colour, margins, element classes. element missing needs created (scope = "all_listed"), cloned current/global theme first sizes never reset.

title: Apply period fonts in place — apply_period_fonts
code: apply_period_fonts(   p,   era = "journal-1960s",   scope = c("base_only", "targeted", "all_listed"),   install_if_missing = TRUE,   use_showtext = FALSE )

title: Apply period fonts in place — apply_period_fonts
text: p ggplot. era One : "journal-1930s","journal-1960s","slide-1970s", "slide-1980s","typewriter-1950s","handdrawn-pen". scope "base_only" (text), "targeted" (also title/subtitle/caption, axis/strip/legend already exist), "all_listed" (force-create missing listed elements cloning template). install_if_missing, use_showtext See .period_families().

title: Apply period fonts in place — apply_period_fonts
text: modified ggplot.

title: Apply period fonts in place — apply_period_fonts
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ if (requireNamespace("ggplot2", quietly = TRUE)) {   p <- ggplot2::ggplot(mtcars, ggplot2::aes(wt, mpg)) + ggplot2::geom_point()   apply_period_fonts(p) } } # }

what: Render a ggplot/grob/gtable to a magick image — as_magick
title: Render a ggplot/grob/gtable to a magick image — as_magick
text: Render ggplot/grob/gtable magick image

title: Render a ggplot/grob/gtable to a magick image — as_magick
code: as_magick(x, width = 6, height = 4, dpi = 300, bg = "white")

title: Render a ggplot/grob/gtable to a magick image — as_magick
text: x ggplot, grob, gtable. width, height Plot size inches. dpi Resolution rasterization. bg Background color.

title: Render a ggplot/grob/gtable to a magick image — as_magick
text: magick-image.

title: Render a ggplot/grob/gtable to a magick image — as_magick
code: if (requireNamespace("ggplot2", quietly = TRUE)) {   p <- ggplot2::ggplot(mtcars, ggplot2::aes(wt, mpg)) +     ggplot2::geom_point()   as_magick(p) } #> # A tibble: 1 × 7 #>   format width height colorspace matte filesize density #>   <chr>  <int>  <int> <chr>      <lgl>    <int> <chr>   #> 1 PNG     1800   1200 sRGB       FALSE    44055 118x118

what: ggpatina: Period Aesthetics and Analog Aging Effects for Figures — ggpatina-package
title: ggpatina: Period Aesthetics and Analog Aging Effects for Figures — ggpatina-package
text: Provides period-inspired fonts analog-aging visual effects figures. Includes presets transparency slides old journal scans, plus ink bleed, Kodachrome-style fade, photocopy misalignment, blueprint (cyanotype) style.

title: ggpatina: Period Aesthetics and Analog Aging Effects for Figures — ggpatina-package
text: Maintainer: John Prybylski jprybylski@gmail.com (ORCID) [copyright holder]

what: Save a ggplot with showtext enabled temporarily — ggsave_st
title: Save a ggplot with showtext enabled temporarily — ggsave_st
text: Wraps ggplot2::ggsave() activating showtext call, ensuring font rendering without leaving global side effects.

title: Save a ggplot with showtext enabled temporarily — ggsave_st
code: ggsave_st(filename, plot, ...)

title: Save a ggplot with showtext enabled temporarily — ggsave_st
text: filename File name create disk. plot Plot save, defaults last plot displayed. ... arguments passed graphics device function, specified device.

title: Save a ggplot with showtext enabled temporarily — ggsave_st
text: file path, invisibly.

title: Save a ggplot with showtext enabled temporarily — ggsave_st
code: if (requireNamespace("ggplot2", quietly = TRUE)) {   p <- ggplot2::qplot(wt, mpg, data = mtcars)   ggsave_st("example.png", p) } #> Warning: `qplot()` was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. #> Saving 6.67 x 6.67 in image

title: Hand-drawn wobble — hand_drawn_wiggle
text: Adds sketchy wobble automatic scaling panel masking.

title: Hand-drawn wobble — hand_drawn_wiggle
code: hand_drawn_wiggle(   x,   width = 6,   height = 4,   dpi = 300,   scale = "auto",   strength = 0.7,   freq = 0.6,   seed = 3,   affect_text = TRUE,   focus = c("panel", "full", "auto_image"),   expand_px = c(6L, 6L),   edge_guard = 0.03,   fill_bg = NULL )

title: Hand-drawn wobble — hand_drawn_wiggle
text: x ggplot/grob magick-image width, height, dpi Used x ggplot/grob scale numeric px "auto" (default) strength 0..1 intensity scale="auto" (default 0.7) freq noise frequency (0.2 broad … 1.2 fine) seed RNG seed affect_text FALSE, confine warp panel region focus "panel" (default ggplot), "full", "auto_image" expand_px integer px expand panel box (ggplot path) edge_guard fade warp near canvas edges (0..0.2) fill_bg final background (e.g., "white" "transparent")

title: Hand-drawn wobble — hand_drawn_wiggle
text: magick-image

title: Hand-drawn wobble — hand_drawn_wiggle
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ if (requireNamespace("ggplot2", quietly = TRUE)) {   p <- ggplot2::ggplot(mtcars, ggplot2::aes(wt, mpg)) + ggplot2::geom_point()   hand_drawn_wiggle(p) } } # }

what: Pixel mask for the ggplot plotting region (panel + axes, optional) — panel_mask_from_plot
title: Pixel mask for the ggplot plotting region (panel + axes, optional) — panel_mask_from_plot
text: Builds feathered rectangular mask device pixels tightly covers visible plotting region. default unions panel viewport(s) axis viewports, matches user expectations want wobble confined “plot area axes” excluding titles/margins/legends.

title: Pixel mask for the ggplot plotting region (panel + axes, optional) — panel_mask_from_plot
code: panel_mask_from_plot(   p,   width,   height,   dpi,   feather = 10,   expand_px = c(0L, 0L),   include_axes = TRUE,   vp_min_in = c(0.25, 0.25),   debug = FALSE,   return_bbox = FALSE )

title: Pixel mask for the ggplot plotting region (panel + axes, optional) — panel_mask_from_plot
text: p ggplot object. width, height, dpi Output device size (inches, DPI) used layout mask. feather Gaussian feather radius (px) mask edge. expand_px Integer vector c(x, y) padding (px) added side. include_axes Logical; TRUE (default) include axis viewports union. vp_min_in Numeric vector c(w_in, h_in) minimum inches accept viewport. debug Logical; TRUE, prints viewport names bbox pixels. return_bbox Logical; TRUE, returns list mask bbox (useful caching visual debug). Default FALSE returns just mask.

title: Pixel mask for the ggplot plotting region (panel + axes, optional) — panel_mask_from_plot
text: magick-image mask (white = inside, black = outside); list return_bbox=TRUE.

title: Blueprint style — patina_blueprint
text: Creates cyanotype blueprint effect optional grid paper texture.

title: Blueprint style — patina_blueprint
code: patina_blueprint(   img,   bg = "#0e4a7b",   grid = FALSE,   grid_px = 48,   paper_texture = NULL,   line_soften = 0.5 )

title: Blueprint style — patina_blueprint
text: img magick image. bg Blueprint background color. grid Logical; overlay white grid. grid_px Grid spacing pixels. paper_texture Optional paper texture. line_soften Gaussian sigma softening line mask.

title: Blueprint style — patina_blueprint
text: magick-image blueprint effect.

title: Old educational film preset — patina_edu_film

title: Old educational film preset — patina_edu_film
code: patina_edu_film(   img,   warmth = 0.35,   grain = 0.45,   vignette = 0.22,   jitter = 0.4,   dust = 0.25,   dust_n = NULL,   dust_size_px = c(0.6, 2.2),   dust_polarity = c("white", "black", "mixed"),   dust_mix = 0.5,   seed = NULL,   scratches = 6L )

title: Old educational film preset — patina_edu_film
text: img magick image warmth 0..1 warm/green cast (0=none) grain 0..1 coarse film grain vignette 0..1 edge darkening jitter small rotation degrees mimic gate weave dust 0..1 dust amount scaler (0 = none) dust_n integer, override number dust specks (NULL = auto size × dust) dust_size_px length-2 numeric, min/max speck radius pixels dust_polarity one "white","black","mixed" dust_mix 0..1 fraction black specks dust_polarity="mixed" seed optional integer make dust/scratches reproducible scratches integer number vertical scratches draw (0 = none)

title: Old newscast effect — patina_newscast
text: Adds scanlines, chroma bleed, tube glow, vignette, noise mimic CRT broadcast.

title: Old newscast effect — patina_newscast
code: patina_newscast(   img,   sat = 1,   scan_strength = 0.28,   scan_period = 4L,   ca_px = 1L,   glow = 0.25,   vignette = 0.18,   noise = 0.25,   warp = c("none", "full", "corner"),   warp_amount = 0.06,   corner = c("ne", "nw", "se", "sw"),   corner_frac = 0.52,   corner_margin = 0.04 )

title: Old newscast effect — patina_newscast
text: img magick image sat saturation multiplier (1 = unchanged) scan_strength 0..1 strength scanlines scan_period integer px per dark line (e.g., 3–5) ca_px integer pixel shift R/B channels (chromatic aberration) glow 0..1 highlight bloom vignette 0..1 edge darkening noise 0..1 CRT noise/grain warp one "none","full","corner" warp_amount curvature amount warp (typ. 0.03–0.10) corner corner corner-warp: "ne","nw","se","sw" corner_frac size warped corner region fraction width/height (0.3–0.8) corner_margin fraction margin edges placing corner region

title: Old newspaper effect — patina_newspaper

title: Old newspaper effect — patina_newspaper
text: img magick image (rasterized plot) halftone 0..1 strength dot pattern (applied background ) dot_map dithering map (e.g. "h6x6o","h4x4a") ink_spread px radius outward bleed around dark strokes ink_strength 0..1 strength bleed halo paper optional path/URL paper texture; NULL tint used paper_tint hex color newsprint paper_blend 0..1 blend paper texture/tint misregister_px integer pixel C/M plate offset (0 = ) exposure overall brightness multiplier (~0.95–1.15) highlight_lift 0..1 brighten light backgrounds line_gain 0..1 deepen ink strokes effects

title: Photocopier double-pass effect — patina_photocopy
text: img magick image offset c(x,y) ghost offset px ghost_opacity 0..1 opacity ghost pass banding 0..1 banding strength tilt_deg rotate (deskew) degrees protect_lines 0..1 strongly protect dark strokes (1 = max) wash 0..1 much lift paper/background (0 = none, 1 = strong) line_gain 0..1 re-ink amount applied effects (0 = none) contrast_pop strength final sigmoid contrast (0 = none)

title: Photocopier double-pass effect — patina_photocopy

title: Period font theme — period_font_theme
text: Returns theme swaps font families preserving sizes current global theme.

title: Period font theme — period_font_theme
code: period_font_theme(   era = c("journal-1930s", "journal-1960s", "slide-1970s", "slide-1980s",     "typewriter-1950s", "handdrawn-pen"),   scope = c("base_only", "targeted", "all_listed"),   install_if_missing = TRUE,   use_showtext = FALSE )

title: Period font theme — period_font_theme
text: era One : "journal-1930s","journal-1960s","slide-1970s", "slide-1980s","typewriter-1950s","handdrawn-pen". scope "base_only" (text), "targeted" (also title/subtitle/caption, axis/strip/legend already exist), "all_listed" (force-create missing listed elements cloning template). install_if_missing, use_showtext See .period_families().

title: Period font theme — period_font_theme
text: ggplot2::theme changes font families listed elements.

title: Period font theme — period_font_theme
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ if (requireNamespace("ggplot2", quietly = TRUE)) {   ggplot2::ggplot(mtcars, ggplot2::aes(wt, mpg)) +     ggplot2::geom_point() +     period_font_theme() } } # }

title: Journal-style theme core — theme_journal_core
text: Conservative scaffold journals: clear axes, restrained grids, white backgrounds, font-size changes plays nicely font helpers.

title: Journal-style theme core — theme_journal_core
code: theme_journal_core(   base_size = 11,   base_family = NULL,   grid_major_y = TRUE,   grid_major_x = FALSE,   grid_minor = FALSE,   panel_border = TRUE,   strip_border = TRUE,   axis_ticks_inside = TRUE )

title: Journal-style theme core — theme_journal_core
text: base_size Numeric base text size passed ggplot2::theme_minimal(). Defaults 11. change sizes already set explicitly. base_family Optional base font family. Leave NULL inherit. grid_major_y, grid_major_x Logical; draw major grids Y / X? grid_minor Logical; draw minor grids? panel_border Logical; draw thin black panel border? strip_border Logical; draw thin border around facet strips? axis_ticks_inside Logical; TRUE ticks point inward.

title: Journal-style theme core — theme_journal_core
text: ggplot2::theme object.

title: Journal-style theme core — theme_journal_core
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ if (requireNamespace("ggplot2", quietly = TRUE)) {   library(ggplot2)   p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg)) + geom_point()   p + theme_journal_core() } } # }
